title: How to Remove Black Flaking in a Jetted Bathtub

steps.headline: Don't use bleach.
steps.description: First things first, we don't use bleach because over time it will breakdown gaskets, bushings, etc. We also won't use any dishwashing detergent since it will put a coating layer on the flaking we are trying to remove.

steps.headline: Fill the jetted tub up with warm water 1" about the highest jet.
Add a non toxic bio cleaner to the water per the instructions on the cleaning product label, normally it is 1 teaspoon or 1 capful, depending upon the bio cleaner
Run the jets, turn off the air valve if you have one, on high for 10-15 minutes.
steps.description: This allows the bio cleaner to scrape off the gunk (flakes) that are solidified on the pipe and jet walls. Bio Cleaners use special properties that are ecological, green and non toxic and have the capability to eradicate bacteria, algae, mold, mildew, dead skin, soaps, and other gunk in the piping and remove them to the sides of the tub.

steps.headline: When you have completed the 10-15 cleaning cycle, remove 2 inches (5.1 cm) of water, clean the "ring around the tub", refill with 2 inches (5.1 cm) of water and repeat the process.
steps.description: You will have to add more bio cleaner in as well.

steps.headline: To maintain a clean jetted tub, you really need to clean it once a week, preferably after a bath to save on water.
